posts.creator: Egor Bogomolov
posts.title: The Future of AI in Software Development
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
AI is no longer a distant idea. It‚Äôs already here and changing how we build software. As it advances, new questions emerge about its impact.¬†
How deeply will AI be woven into software development? What new opportunities will emerge for companies building AI-powered tools? Perhaps most importantly, how will developers and AI collaborate over the next three to five years?
The AI 2027 outlook highlights the need for practical use, domain-specific design, and a focus on real results over hype.
In this article, we‚Äôll offer insights into how AI is transforming the development landscape today and its potential impact on software development over the coming decade. Here‚Äôs an in-depth look at the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead for developers and organizations.
Two possible futures
We‚Äôll explore two potential timelines for the future: one where AGI fundamentally reshapes software development, and another where AI merely enhances our current practices.
Here‚Äôs a quick recap of the trends we‚Äôll have to stay on top of in order to know which future we‚Äôre headed toward:
First off is the rise of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), where machines gain human-like cognitive abilities. OpenAI‚Äôs CEO, Sam Altman, has expressed confidence about AGI being right around the corner. However, experts like Meta‚Äôs Yann LeCun are more cautious, arguing that current systems remain far from that goal.
At Google I/O 2025, Google introduced Gemini 2.5 Pro with ‚ÄúDeep Think‚Äù reasoning, plus new tools like AI Mode for Search and Gemini Flow for video generation.¬†
Alternatively, AI is enhancing software development through advanced tools that assist developers in coding and problem-solving. Platforms like GitHub Copilot or JetBrains AI integrate models from various AI research organizations, allowing developers to choose the most effective AI assistance for their specific tasks.¬†
Tools such as JetBrains Junie, Cursor Composer, Codex, or Windsurf Flows enable automating various tasks at the codebase level at a rate unimaginable before. This integration boosts productivity and democratizes coding.
As AI continues to evolve, the software development landscape stands at a crossroads between the pursuit of AGI and the augmentation of human capabilities through AI-powered tools.
Scenario 1: A full-blown AI future¬†
As technology gets closer and closer to the level of AGI, we‚Äôre beginning to see AI agents that don‚Äôt just assist, but actively write code. These systems can handle complex engineering tasks, with capabilities approaching those of senior-level developers. Early examples include Devin, which can plan and execute full development workflows, and Honeycomb, which integrates autonomous agents into real-world software pipelines. In systems evaluation, progress is often measured using benchmarks like SWE-bench, which focuses on resolving localized GitHub issues. Taken together, these efforts mark the emergence of autonomous AI agents that we can call ‚ÄúAI developers‚Äù.
We can even imagine AI developers eventually working together in teams, much the same way humans do today, with each having its own specialized area (development, testing, project coordination, etc.). This idea is gaining traction in research. Examples include RepoAgent, which applies multiple agents to full-stack tasks in real repositories, and AgentCoder, which simulates collaborative agent roles throughout the software workflow.
AI developers need a home, too
AI developers will demand their own workspace ecosystem. This isn‚Äôt just a theoretical concept ‚Äì it‚Äôs an immediate challenge facing organizations integrating AI into their development workflows.
This evolution will unfold naturally over the next few years, from enhanced ML capabilities in enterprise environments to fully customizable AI developer solutions. For some AI developers, this ‚Äúhome‚Äù may exist within centralized cloud-based platforms.
For others, local inference offers an alternative path. Tools like Ollama already allow powerful models to run directly on consumer hardware. With quantization, even 30B+ parameter models can run locally on high-end GPUs, opening the door to secure, offline-first AI development environments. Organizations that recognize and adapt to this shift early will gain a meaningful edge on the AI-driven development landscape.
AI teams need tools
As teams of AI developers (let‚Äôs call them ‚ÄúAI teams‚Äù) become more advanced, they‚Äôll need specialized tools to manage every part of their workflow, from coding and testing to handling documentation and requirements. The AutoCodeRover team was among the first to show how advanced tools make it far easier for agents to solve problems. Since then, we‚Äôve seen an uptick in environments and platforms for AI developers: hide, OpenHands, and others. AI teams rely on robust, integrated platforms, just like humans do.
The ultimate breakthrough would be a platform that gives AI models direct, seamless access to all the essential tools in one centralized space. This setup would allow AI developers to operate as smoothly as human developers within a single interface by eliminating the need for complex integrations.¬†
Early efforts in this direction include OpenAI‚Äôs Computer-Using Agent (CUA), which enables models to interact with existing software on a desktop, and Anthropic‚Äôs ComputerUse, which gives Claude the ability to control full computing environments.¬†
Both approaches reflect a shared goal: equipping AI developers with the same types of digital toolkits that humans use.
Humans need next-generation IDEs to collaborate with AI teams¬†
Even with AI teams doing the heavy lifting, we‚Äôll still need humans to guide, refine, and approve the final product. Next-generation IDEs will be essential for this, bridging the gap between human insight and AI productivity.
In fact, there‚Äôs an entire new field of study emerging, known as Human-AI eXperience (HAX). This field is all about finding efficient ways for human developers to interact with their AI tools. Soon enough, we‚Äôll be faced with a flood of AI-generated code, and we‚Äôll need IDEs that can understand and verify this code for us, while we humans stay focused on the big picture stuff (setting requirements, visualizing project progress, etc.).
At JetBrains, we‚Äôre exploring more effective ways for humans to collaborate with AI systems, including ongoing experiments like AIR. We‚Äôre staying on top of broader developments in this space, and view tools like Claude Code, Warp AI, Gemini CLI, Google Jules, Cursor, Coedium, and DevGPT as strongly indicative of how the landscape is shifting.
AI teams need a marketplace
As AI developers produce more code, they‚Äôll need a dedicated marketplace ‚Äì a central hub for storing, finding, and reusing AI-generated code (like GitHub for AI agents).
Existing platforms aren‚Äôt built for this use case. They assume human intent, manual review, and slow feedback cycles. An AI-first marketplace would need different foundations, like built-in sandboxing to safely test unknown contributions, automated verification pipelines to check compatibility and quality, and metadata designed to help AI developers understand, rate, and select what they need.
Without these features, reuse becomes risky and inefficient. With them, AI teams can move faster, collaborate safely, and continuously improve shared assets.
AI will face regulations¬†
The AI learning curve isn‚Äôt specific to developers. Lawyers and policymakers will also have to learn the ropes.
The first problem is safety. Obviously AI is not immune to making mistakes, and these mistakes can cause real-world damage. Studies have shown that trustworthy AI code may be a long way off. For the foreseeable future, we should be treating AI-generated code with the same scrutiny that we apply to, say, self-driving cars. Formal audits and certifications are a must.
Secondly, the prevalence of AI may raise new questions about intellectual property and its definitions. For example, when we use publicly available code to train models, are we infringing on the rights of the original authors? Recent lawsuits, such as those involving GitHub Copilot and Open AI, force us to ask this question. Attribution and licensing will only become more complex as AI generates code at scale.
This creates a major opportunity for companies that develop tools to inspect and certify AI-generated code. Tools that can identify AI-created code, flag potential risks, and approve it will protect users and build trust.
Software may look different from the inside¬†
AI developers could end up training themselves, learning and evolving their coding patterns through countless iterations of trial and error. Early work in this direction appeared in 2022, including projects like CodeRL, which applied reinforcement learning to optimize code generation based on execution feedback. While the code might still be written in familiar languages like Java or Kotlin, its structure could be optimized entirely for machine efficiency, not human readability.
An even more frightening thought is that we could end up with new programming languages that don‚Äôt follow any of the patterns we humans are familiar with, as they were designed entirely for AI developers. This isn‚Äôt science fiction ‚Äì it‚Äôs the next frontier in software development, where AI might write code that is essentially unrecognizable to us.
As Erik Meijer outlines in his ACM article, we may soon need to accept a world where code serves machines first, with humans relying on meta-tools to inspect and tweak the output. The result? Faster, more efficient business systems, even if we need new abstractions to understand what‚Äôs going on under the hood.
Software may look the same, but with AI developers choosing their favorites¬†
In the AI era, a language‚Äôs success might depend more on its available codebase than its elegant syntax. It‚Äôs simple math ‚Äì the more code examples available, the better AI can understand that language and generate code in it.
This creates a unique opportunity to position programming languages for AI adoption. The goal isn‚Äôt to replace programming languages, but to develop them for this new collaborative future.¬†
Languages like Rust, with strong memory safety guarantees, or Dafny, which supports formal verification, offer valuable properties in contexts where reliability matters. Others, like Julia, scale well for numerical and data-heavy tasks, making them attractive for AI workflows. The race to become AI‚Äôs preferred programming language is just beginning.
The legacy code challenge
Let‚Äôs talk about the elephant in the room: legacy code. While everyone‚Äôs excited about AI generating new applications, there‚Äôs a trillion-dollar reality we can‚Äôt ignore. We have a massive amount of code powering our world, and it‚Äôs not going anywhere.




The real opportunity here lies in creating smart maintenance solutions that can handle enterprise-scale challenges. Some examples are tools that can help modernize legacy codebases, automatically suggest library updates, and provide deep insights across millions of lines of code.¬†
Scenario 2: AI as an enhancer
In this more conservative vision of the future, AI doesn‚Äôt replace developers, but supercharges their work and transforms the toolkit they rely on. Developers remain firmly in control, and AI merely helps their productivity skyrocket.
Advancement in AI support beyond coding¬†
In the future, activities like debugging, profiling, and configuring development environments are likely to become partially or fully automated. So far, automation has primarily focused on accelerating coding itself. The next generation of AI tools will likely handle a broader range of tasks, such as finding bugs and optimizing performance.
However, even as these tasks are automated, human developers will still be critical in reviewing and verifying the AI‚Äôs work. The challenge will be creating tools that assist in these tasks and build trust, enabling developers to quickly confirm that the AI‚Äôs actions are correct and helpful.
AI developers as part of human teams¬†
Software teams are already moving towards including AI as active contributors. We can see early signs in tools like GitHub bots that fix vulnerabilities without human input. Before long, AI agents could take on everyday tasks like resolving issues, updating documents, and tidying up codebases.
This shift lets developers spend more time on complex, creative work while AI handles the routine upkeep.
IDEs adapted to work with AI developers¬†
This shift is already underway. As AI joins development teams, human developers will need tools to manage these new digital teammates. That means assigning tasks, tracking progress, and reviewing output, all within the IDE.
New, user-friendly interfaces will help developers see what each agent is working on, check task lists, and respond to questions. As AI performs more updates and maintenance, these manager-style tools will become essential. Like any teammate, AI may also reach out for help when needed.
AI assistants beyond development
What if everyone involved in the development process (product managers, QA engineers, DevOps teams, and more) had their own AI helper? We seem to be headed in this direction already, with startups popping up to offer AI-powered assistance to roles outside traditional software engineering.
The end goal? Less time spent on routine tasks and more time for people to focus on strategic work, reviewing results, and making key decisions.
There‚Äôs a boatload of untapped potential for increased productivity here. Now is the time to start exploring what each professional needs from their AI assistant and get a few prototypes up and running.¬†
AI assistants as technical leads
It won‚Äôt be long before AI assistants can act as ‚Äútech leads‚Äù, ready to answer any question you have about your project. LLMs can already handle general questions and give insights on specific sections of code, but for now, only within the highly specific context presented by the prompt.
As these models evolve, they‚Äôll be able to draw from the entire codebase, the project‚Äôs development history, issues from the tracker, team chats, and all documentation.¬†
AI needs control¬†
As AI generates more and more code, we will need ways to keep track of it, verify its quality, and ensure it works as expected. Simply reviewing AI-generated code will not be enough to guarantee its reliability. One likely development is the introduction of Git-level tagging to mark code as AI-generated, making it easier to trace and manage throughout the lifecycle.
This is only part of the picture. We will also need tools designed specifically for testing and auditing code written by machines. Platforms like SonarQube are already evolving to support more automated quality checks, and efforts to build policy-aware validation frameworks are gaining traction.
Looking ahead, companies working in this space may help shape how we standardize, track, and certify AI-generated code. Broader regulatory initiatives are also emerging, such as the EU AI Act and guidance from the US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), both of which emphasise transparency, accountability, and traceability as essential principles for responsible AI use in software development.
AI-powered education
As AI reshapes development, our approach to teaching programming should keep pace. Imagine new devs learning not just to code, but to code in an AI-enhanced environment that mirrors real-world development. By integrating AI into programming education, we can help beginners adopt tools faster and more naturally, setting them up for success with the technologies they‚Äôll use.
Wrapping up: An AI-powered future is inevitable¬†
We‚Äôve looked at current AI trends shaping software development and explored two vastly different AI-driven scenarios. Regardless of what the future holds, one thing is clear: AI will evolve from a supportive assistant into a proactive player in coding, testing, and analysis. This shift will create new roles for developers as guides and reviewers, collaborating closely with AI agents.
As AI automates more routine work and gains richer project context, we‚Äôll need fresh interfaces, reliable verification tools, and adaptable workflows. Preparing for this future means advancing machine learning, experimenting with interfaces, and deepening AI integration. Thanks for joining us on this exploration!

posts.creator: Vlad Ivoninskii
posts.title: Workspace Import From ZIP, Python Update, Collapsible Sections in Notebooks, and More in Datalore 2025.3
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
The 2025.3 release of Datalore delivers multiple long-awaited features, including a new way to import workspaces, default values for text fields, and tools for organizing assets like collapsible sections and report folders. Read on to learn more.
These updates are already available for Datalore Cloud users, and Datalore On-Premises users can get them by updating their Datalore instance.
Python 3.11 in baseline Python images
The default Python interpreter now uses Python 3.11, bringing improvements in performance, security, and library compatibility.
Collapsible sections in notebooks
The new release makes it easier to navigate and review longer notebooks by allowing you to fold consecutive cells located under the same Markdown heading. For example, if you want to make the results and narrative more visible, you can fold code cells. You can also run all cells within a folded section without having to expand it. Learn more.




Preserved context in cloned notebooks
Cloning shared notebooks is now more convenient, as cloned notebooks will retain their original context. If you have editing access to the workspace where the original notebook lives, you won‚Äôt need to manually add environment variables, repositories, and data connections. This means less time spent configuring the setup and more time actually working with data.
Report folders
You can now organize your reports in folders, making your insights and findings easier to maintain, collaborate on, and revisit later. You can keep drafts separate from polished reports, group reports by project, or use any other method that works for you and your team. Learn more.




Workspace import from ZIP
If you have a workspace in a ZIP archive, you can now import it in Datalore and add all notebooks and files at once instead of importing them manually one by one. If your workspace has been exported from Datalore, your original file structure will be recreated. Learn more.





          
      Update to 2025.3

posts.creator: Daniela Bentrup
posts.title: Building Better Agents: What‚Äôs New in Koog 0.3.0
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
We‚Äôve just released Koog 0.3.0, which comes with many updates that make building, running, and managing intelligent agents easier.
This version focuses on durability, speed, observability, and smoother integration with real-world systems. If you‚Äôve been exploring how to develop your own intelligent agent that can handle complex workflows, the new and updated Koog could be just what you‚Äôre looking for. Find it now on GitHub.
Here‚Äôs a breakdown of what‚Äôs new in v0.3.0:
Learn more
Agents that don‚Äôt forget
In Koog 0.3.0, agents can now remember what they were doing. You can save and reload their state from a local disk, S3 buckets, or a database. This powerful feature enables server-side developers to build fault-tolerant agentic solutions by restoring the agent‚Äôs entire state machine at the exact point of strategy execution instead of just recovering the message history.
This means you can shut down machines without losing progress. There‚Äôs also a new checkpoint feature, so agents can roll back to any earlier state if needed.

Smarter storage for better retrieval
Koog now supports persistent vector storage for docs. Whether you‚Äôre working with local files or connecting to a vector database, you can use Koog to build retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipelines.
The setup is modular, allowing you to add support for different formats, ranking methods, and backends.

Built-In observability and moderation for agents
We‚Äôve added native OpenTelemetry support. This means you can now trace, log, and measure your agents using the same tools you‚Äôd use elsewhere in your system, enabling you to spot bottlenecks, track behaviour, and keep things running smoothly.

And if you‚Äôre deploying in regulated environments, there‚Äôs also built-in support for moderation. Agents can now check their own outputs to make sure they‚Äôre appropriate and safe. This is especially useful when trust and compliance are a priority.
Running tasks in parallel
Sometimes your agent graph includes steps that can run independently. Koog now supports parallel execution of those nodes, following a familiar MapReduce-style API.
You can launch several branches simultaneously, transform their results asynchronously, and collect everything at the end. This approach is useful when you want to try multiple strategies at once or speed up multi-step workflows.

A better fit for your stack
Koog now works better with Spring. If you‚Äôre using Spring Boot, you‚Äôll get ready-made beans and auto-configured LLM clients out of the box.
The release also adds support for ReAct-style agent thinking. Agents can now follow step-by-step reasoning paths, switching between thoughts and actions.
You‚Äôll also find updates that help agents handle uncertainty better. The new Retry component makes them more resilient, and multiple-choice reasoning gives them new ways to explore options and respond to user preferences.
A few more things to get excited about
This version brings a handful of other improvements that are worth highlighting:
Agents can now receive image input when running with Ollama-backed models.
Full WebAssembly (WASM) support means you can now deploy Koog agents to the browser.
Native support for Amazon Bedrock has been added.
Fact-retrieval history compression has been improved to help agents focus on the correct data without getting confused by unrelated context.
Agents can now work with arbitrary input and output types, providing greater flexibility in the execution flow.
We‚Äôve also fixed several bugs to make the overall UX smoother.
Koog 0.3.0 is a step toward making agents more robust, portable, and valuable.
Many of these updates were implemented on the basis of community feedback, so thanks to everyone who‚Äôs tried it out, opened issues, or shared ideas. 
If you haven‚Äôt yet, now‚Äôs a good time to try Koog and see what you can build.
Your contributions make the difference
We‚Äôd like to take this opportunity to extend a huge thank-you to the entire community for contributing to the development of Koog through your feedback, issue reports, and pull requests!
Here‚Äôs a list of this release‚Äôs top contributors:
Nathan Fallet Azure OpenAI and other general improvements
Didier Villevalois Ollama updates
Jason Pearson AWS Bedrock improvements
Denys Kurylenko MCP enhancements

posts.creator: Siva Katamreddy
posts.title: Spring Debugger: Working With Dynamic Database Connections Just Got Simpler
posts.content:encodedSnippet:
While building Spring Boot applications, you can leverage Testcontainers to spin up any required services, such as a database or messaging broker, as Docker containers at application startup. This enables a ready-to-code setup, minimizing environment friction so you can focus on delivering high-quality, maintainable code.
For database-driven development, IntelliJ IDEA provides enterprise-grade, professional-level tooling out of the box. You can:
Reverse-engineer JPA entities from an existing schema
Generate Flyway or Liquibase migrations directly from your JPA models
Access a suite of built-in integrations (e.g., SQL consoles, schema diff, and more) that help you maintain a clean, consistent database lifecycle
IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs ergonomic UI and preconfigured environments allow you to code faster, refactor more smoothly, and catch potential issues before they become bugs. This means that using IntelliJ IDEA combined with Testcontainers is a productivity booster. However, there is just one problem‚Ä¶
Testcontainers map container ports to random host ports to avoid conflicts. Each time you restart your application, you must fetch the new mapped port and manually update IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs DataSource connection properties.




JetBrains addressed this problem with the Spring Debugger plugin. It automatically registers the DataSource connection to any relational databases started by Testcontainers. Additionally, the DataSource connection will be automatically created while running Testcontainers tests. You can use the Spring Debugger plugin with IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate 2025.1.2 or any later versions.
NOTE: Spring Debugger automatic DataSource registration works with Testcontainers and Docker Compose too.
You can also watch the demonstration of Spring Debugger plugin‚Äôs automatic DataSource registration feature in this video.


Spring Debugger: Working With Dynamic Database Connections Just Got Simpler



Let‚Äôs explore this feature using a practical example.
Local development using Testcontainers
To follow along, clone the Spring Boot sample project from here.
This repository contains a Spring Boot REST API project using the starters Spring Web, Validation, Spring Data JPA, PostgreSQL Driver, Flyway Migration, and Testcontainers.
Open the project in IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate and run TestBookmarksApplication.java in debug mode to start the application.




As you can see, when you start the application, Testcontainers start a PostgreSQL database, and a PostgreSQL DataSource is automatically registered in IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs Database tool window.
NOTE: The DataSource will be automatically registered ONLY when you start the application in debug mode.
When you stop the application, the registered DataSource will be automatically deleted from the Database tool window.
Debugging Testcontainers based tests
A DataSource is automatically registered both when running the application and when running tests. You can run your Testcontainers-based tests in debug mode, set a breakpoint, and explore the data in your database.
Here is an example of running a Spring Boot integration test that interacts with a PostgreSQL database started by Testcontainers.




As you can see, while running the test, we can set a breakpoint and verify the data in the database if needed.
Here is another example of debugging a Spring Data JPA Repository test using @DataJpaTest.




Local development and testing with MongoDB
In addition to the relational databases, the automatic registration of the DataSource works for MongoDB as well.




Summary
IntelliJ IDEA‚Äôs automatic registration of Testcontainers data sources in the Database tool window eliminates the need for manually registering the DataSources. This makes local development and debugging of the Testcontainers tests using databases much simpler.
As of now, this feature works for relational databases and MongoDB only, but support for more databases will be added in upcoming IntelliJ IDEA versions.
To learn more about the features of the Spring Debugger plugin, please read the documentation.
What are you waiting for? Download the latest version of IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate and install the Spring Debugger plugin and try the features of its plugin for yourself.

posts.title: Ìá¥ÏÇ¨ Î∂ÄÍ≤Ä : ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÎ•º Îñ†ÎÇòÎ©∞
posts.author: ÌÉúÌÉúÌÉú
posts.content:
„ÄÄ12ÎÖÑ ÎÑòÍ≤å Îã§Îãå ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º Îñ†ÎÇúÎã§. Íµ∞ÎåÄÎ•º Ï†ÑÏó≠Ìïú Ïù¥ÌõÑ, Ïä§Ïä§Î°úÏùò ÏÑ†ÌÉùÏúºÎ°ú ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º Îñ†ÎÇòÎäî Í≤ÉÏùÄ Ïù¥Î≤àÏù¥ Ï≤òÏùåÏù¥Îã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑúÏù∏ÏßÄ ÏïÑÏßÅ Ïã§Í∞êÏù¥ ÎÇòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäîÎã§. Ï≤´ Ï∂úÍ∑º ÎÇ†Ïùò ÏÑ§Î†òÏù¥ ÏïÑÏßÅÎèÑ ÏÜêÎÅùÏóê ÎÇ®ÏïÑ ÏûàÎäîÎç∞, Ïñ¥ÎäêÏÉà ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ Ìá¥Í∑ºÏùÑ Ï§ÄÎπÑÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§. ÌïòÎ£®ÏóêÎèÑ Î™á Î≤àÏî© ÏïÑÏâ¨ÏõÄÍ≥º ÌõÑÎ†®Ìï®, ÏÑ§Î†òÍ≥º ÎëêÎ†§ÏõÄÏù¥ Î≤àÍ∞àÏïÑ Ï∞æÏïÑÏò®Îã§. Í∞êÏ†ïÏùÄ Î∞ÄÎ¨ºÏ≤òÎüº Îì§Ïñ¥ÏôîÎã§Í∞Ä Ïç∞Î¨ºÏ≤òÎüº Îπ†Ï†∏ÎÇòÍ∞ÑÎã§. Í∏¥ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùò Î¨¥Í≤åÍ∞Ä ÎßàÏùå ÌïúÌé∏Ïóê Ï°∞Ïö©Ìûà Í∞ÄÎùºÏïâÎäîÎã§.

„ÄÄÎààÏùÑ Í∞êÍ≥† Ï≤úÏ≤úÌûà ÏßÄÎÇú ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ Îñ†Ïò¨Î†§ Î≥∏Îã§. Ïã†ÏûÖÏÇ¨ÏõêÏù¥Îçò ÏãúÏ†à, ÏÑ∏ÏÉÅÏù¥ ÎÇ¥ ÏÜêÏïàÏóê ÏûàÎäî ÎìØÌïú ÏûêÏã†Í∞êÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. Ï≤´ ÏóÖÎ¨¥Í∞Ä ÏõπÌéòÏù¥ÏßÄ ÌïòÎã®Ïùò ÏÇ¨Î™ÖÏùÑ NHNÏóêÏÑú NAVERÎ°ú Î∞îÍæ∏Îäî ÏùºÏù¥ÏóàÏúºÎãà, ÏßÄÍ∏à ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥ Ï∞∏ Í∑ÄÏóΩÍ≥† ÏÜåÎ∞ïÌñàÎã§. ÎèôÎ£åÎì§Í≥º ÏõÉÍ≥† Îñ†Îì§Îçò Ï†êÏã¨ÏãúÍ∞ÑÎèÑ, Ïù¥Î£® ÎßêÌï† Ïàò ÏóÜÎäî ÎøåÎìØÌï®ÏùÑ ÏïàÍ≥† Î≥¥ÎÉàÎçò ÏàòÎßéÏùÄ ÏïºÍ∑ºÏùò Î∞§ÎèÑ ÏÉùÏÉùÌïòÎã§. Î¨ºÎ°† Í∑∏ Î∞òÏßùÏù¥Îäî ÏàúÍ∞ÑÎì§ ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ïóî ÌûòÎì§Í≥† Ïô∏Î°úÏö¥ ÎÇ†ÎèÑ ÏûàÏóàÎã§. ÎïåÎ°úÎäî ÏßÄÏπòÍ≥†, ÎïåÎ°úÎäî ÎßâÎßâÌñàÎã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÎèÑ ÎÇòÎäî Í∑∏ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ ÏÇ¨ÎûëÌñàÎã§. Í∑∏ Î™®Îì† ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÏßÄÍ∏àÏùò ÎÇòÎ•º ÎßåÎì§ÏóàÎã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÏÑú Îçî Ïï†ÌããÌïòÎã§. Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Îñ†ÎÇòÏßÄÎßå, Ïù¥ ÌöåÏÇ¨Îäî ÎÇ¥ ÏïàÏóê ÏßÄÏö∏ Ïàò ÏóÜÎäî ÌùîÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇ®ÎäîÎã§.

„ÄÄÏù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÄ Îã®ÏßÄ Ìá¥ÏÇ¨Ïùò Í∏∞Î°ùÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÎã§. ÎÇò ÏûêÏã†Í≥ºÏùò ÍπäÏùÄ ÎåÄÌôîÏù¥Ïûê, Ïª§Î¶¨Ïñ¥Ïùò Ï†ÑÌôòÏ†êÏóê ÎåÄÌïú Í≥†Î∞±Ïù¥Îã§. Î¨¥ÏóáÏùÑ Î∞∞Ïõ†Í≥†, Î¨¥ÏóáÏùÑ ÎÇ®Í∏∞Í≥† Í∞ÄÎäîÏßÄ. ÏïûÏúºÎ°ú Ïñ¥Îñ§ Î∞©Ìñ•ÏùÑ Ìñ•Ìï¥ ÎÇòÏïÑÍ∞àÏßÄ. ÎÇòÎäî ÏßÄÍ∏à Í∑∏ ÏßàÎ¨∏Îì§ ÏïûÏóê ÏÑú ÏûàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÎ°ú Î™®Îì† Í≤ÉÏùÑ Îã¥ÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÏßÄ Î™®Î•¥Í≤†Îã§. Í∑∏ÎûòÎèÑ Ï≤úÏ≤úÌûà, Ìïú Ï§Ñ Ìïú Ï§Ñ Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìï¥Î≥¥Î†§ ÌïúÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏù¥ ÎàÑÍµ∞Í∞ÄÏóêÍ≤å, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Ïñ∏Ï††Í∞ÄÏùò ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å ÏùòÎØ∏ ÏûàÎäî Í∏∞Î°ùÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇ®Í∏∞Î•º Î∞îÎûÄÎã§.

ÎÑ∑ÌîåÎ¶≠Ïä§ÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÏßÅÏõêÏù¥ Ìá¥ÏÇ¨ÌïòÍ∏∞ Ï†ÑÏóê ‚ÄòÌá¥ÏÇ¨Î∂ÄÍ≤Ä‚ÄôÏù¥ÎùºÎäî Î©îÏùºÏùÑ Î≥¥ÎÇ∏Îã§Í≥† ÌïúÎã§. Í∑∏ Î©îÏùºÏóêÎäî ÏïÑÎûòÏùò ÎÇ¥Ïö©Ïù¥ Îã¥Í∏¥Îã§.

  1. Ïôú Îñ†ÎÇòÎäîÏßÄ : Îã§Î•∏ ÏßÅÏõêÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥Ìï¥Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Ïù¥Ïú†
  2. ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏóêÏÑú Î∞∞Ïö¥ Í≤É : ÏÉàÎ°ú Î∞∞Ïö¥ Í≤ÉÍ≥º Í≤ΩÌóòÌïú Í≤É
  3. ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê ÏïÑÏâ¨Ïö¥ Ï†ê : ÌöåÏÇ¨Í∞Ä Ïù¥Îû¨Îã§Î©¥ Îñ†ÎÇòÏßÄ ÏïäÏïòÏùÑ Í≤É
  4. ÏïûÏúºÎ°úÏùò Í≥ÑÌöç : Ïñ¥Îäê ÏßÅÏû•ÏóêÏÑú Ïñ¥Îñ§ ÏóÖÎ¨¥Î•º Ìï†ÏßÄ
  5. ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Î©îÏÑ∏ÏßÄ : ÏßÅÏõêÏùÑ Îñ†ÎÇòÎ≥¥ÎÇ¥Îäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò ÏûÖÏû•

„ÄÄÏù¥ ÌòïÏãùÏùÑ Îî∞Îùº, Í±¥Í∞ïÌïú Ìá¥ÏÇ¨Î•º ÏúÑÌïú Í∏∞Î°ùÏùÑ ÎÇ®Í∏∞Î†§ ÌïúÎã§. Îã§Îßå 5Î≤à Ìï≠Î™©ÏùÄ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï† Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥ ÏïÑÎãàÍ∏∞Ïóê ÏÉùÎûµÌïúÎã§. ÎåÄÏã† ÏãúÏûëÏóê ÏïûÏÑú ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÎùºÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÏùÑ ÏßßÍ≤å Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ≥† ÏãúÏûëÌïúÎã§.

Î∂ÄÍ≤Ä 0 : ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÏóê ÎåÄÌïòÏó¨

„ÄÄÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÎäî ÎåÄÌïúÎØºÍµ≠ ÏµúÎåÄÏùò Í≤ÄÏÉâ ÏóîÏßÑÏù¥Ïûê Ìè¨ÌÑ∏ ÏÇ¨Ïù¥Ìä∏Îã§. Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÏù¥Ïûê ÏßÅÏõêÏúºÎ°úÏÑúÎèÑ Îã§ÎãàÍ∏∞Ïóê Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌöåÏÇ¨Î°ú Ïú†Î™ÖÌïòÎã§. ÎÇò Ïó≠Ïãú Ïû¨ÏßÅ Í∏∞Í∞Ñ ÎèôÏïà ÏàòÎßéÏùÄ Î≥µÏßÄÏôÄ ÌòúÌÉùÏùÑ ÎàÑÎ¶¥ Ïàò ÏûàÏóàÎã§. ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê Ï§ëÏã¨Ïùò ‚ÄòÏÑúÎπÑÏä§‚ÄôÎ•º ÎßåÎìúÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Îùº Î≥µÏû°Ìïú ÎèÑÎ©îÏù∏ ÏÑ§Í≥ÑÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ ÎåÄÍ∑úÎ™® Ìä∏ÎûòÌîΩÏùÑ Îã§Î£∞ Í∏∞ÌöåÎèÑ ÎßéÏïòÎã§. Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÏù∏ ÎÇ¥Í≤å Îß§Ïö∞ Îß§Î†•Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏù¥ÏóàÎã§.

„ÄÄÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÏóêÎäî ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§ÎßàÎã§ Îã§ÏñëÌïú Ï°∞ÏßÅÏù¥ Ï°¥Ïû¨ÌïúÎã§. ÏßÅÏõê Ïä§Ïä§Î°ú ÏÉàÎ°úÏö¥ Í∏∞ÌöåÎ•º Ï∞æÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÎäî OCC(Open Career Chance)ÎùºÎäî ÏÇ¨ÎÇ¥ Ï†úÎèÑÎèÑ ÏûàÎã§. Î¨ºÎ°† ÏµúÍ∑º Îì§Ïñ¥ Ìï©Í≤©Ïùò Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏù¥ ÍπåÎã§Î°úÏõåÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÏßÄÎßå, Ïó¨Ï†ÑÌûà ÏßÅÏõêÎì§Ïù¥ ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÎ•º Ï¢ãÏïÑÌïòÎäî Ïù¥Ïú† Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïúÎã§. ÎòêÌïú ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÏóî ‚ÄúÏµúÎ≥µÎèô(ÏµúÍ≥†Ïùò Î≥µÏßÄÎäî ÎèôÎ£å)‚ÄùÏù¥ÎùºÎäî ÎßêÏù¥ ÏûàÎã§. Ïú†Ïó∞ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûêÏú®Ï†ÅÏù∏ Î∂ÑÏúÑÍ∏∞ ÏÜçÏóêÏÑú ÏÑúÎ°ú Î∞∞Ïö∞Í≥† ÏÑ±Ïû•ÌïòÎäî Î¨∏ÌôîÍ∞Ä Ïûò ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°ÌòÄ ÏûàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü∞ ÎèôÎ£åÎì§Í≥º Ìï®ÍªòÌïú Í≤ÉÏùÄ ÎÇ¥Í≤å ÌÅ∞ ÌñâÏö¥Ïù¥ÏóàÎã§.

„ÄÄÍ∞úÎ∞ú Ïó≠ÎüâÏùÑ ÌÇ§Ïö∞Í≥† Í∏∞Ïà† Ìä∏Î†åÎìúÎ•º Îî∞ÎùºÍ∞ÄÍ∏∞ÏóêÎèÑ Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏù¥Îã§. ‚ÄòÏ±ÖÏûÑÍ∑ºÎ¨¥Ï†ú‚ÄôÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Í∞úÏù∏Ïù¥ Í∑ºÎ¨¥ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏùÑ ÏûêÏú®Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Í¥ÄÎ¶¨Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî Í≤ÉÎèÑ ÎÑ§Ïù¥Î≤ÑÏùò Îß§Î†•Ïù¥Îã§. Ïù¥ÌÜ†Î°ù Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏóêÏÑú Ïò§Îûú ÏãúÍ∞Ñ Ìï®ÍªòÌñàÏßÄÎßå Í≤∞Íµ≠ Îñ†ÎÇòÍ∏∞Î°ú ÌñàÎã§. ÌöåÏÇ¨ÏôÄ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏõêÌïòÎäî Î∞©Ìñ•Ïù¥ Ï†êÏ†ê Îã¨ÎùºÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÏóàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. ÏßÄÍ∏àÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞Îäî Í∑∏ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º Ìï¥Î≥¥Î†§Í≥† ÌïúÎã§. Ïôú Îñ†ÎÇòÍ∏∞Î°ú ÌñàÎäîÏßÄ, Ïñ¥Îñ§ Í≥†ÎØºÏù¥ ÏûàÏóàÎäîÏßÄ. Ï≤úÏ≤úÌûà, ÏÜîÏßÅÌïòÍ≤å.

Î∂ÄÍ≤Ä 1 : Ïôú Îñ†ÎÇòÎäîÍ∞Ä

„ÄÄ12ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà ÏûêÏùò Î∞ò, ÌÉÄÏùò Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú Îã§ÏñëÌïú ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º Í≤ΩÌóòÌñàÎã§. Ïñ¥Îäê ÎÇ† Í∞ëÏûêÍ∏∞ Îã§Î•∏ ÏÑúÎπÑÏä§Î•º Îß°ÏúºÎùºÎäî ÏßÄÏãúÎ•º Î∞õÍ≥† ÌåÄÏùÑ ÏòÆÍ∏∞Í∏∞ÎèÑ ÌñàÎã§. ÎïåÎ°úÎäî Îçî ÌÅ∞ ÎèÑÏ†ÑÏùÑ ÏúÑÌï¥ Ïä§Ïä§Î°ú OCCÎ•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Ïù¥ÎèôÌñàÎã§. ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïùò Í≤ΩÏòÅÏ†Å Ïù¥ÏäàÎÇò Ï°∞ÏßÅ Í∞úÌé∏ÏúºÎ°ú Ïù∏Ìï¥ ÏõêÏπò ÏïäÎäî ÌåÄ Ïù¥ÎèôÏùÑ Í≤™Í∏∞ÎèÑ ÌñàÎã§. Ïû¶ÏùÄ Î≥ÄÌôî ÏÜçÏóê Ïù¥ÏßÅÏùÑ Í≥†ÎØºÌï† Í≤®Î•ºÏ°∞Ï∞® ÏóÜÏóàÎã§. Îß§ ÏàúÍ∞Ñ Í∏¥Ïû•Í≥º ÎèÑÏ†ÑÏùò Ïó∞ÏÜçÏù¥ÏóàÍ≥†, ÌöåÏÇ¨ ÏûêÏ≤¥Í∞Ä Ïã´ÏóàÎçò Ï†ÅÏùÄ ÏóÜÏóàÎã§. posts.title: ÎÇòÎèÑ Ïù¥Ï†ú ÏûëÍ∞Ä! AIÎ°ú ÏôÑÏÑ±ÌïòÎäî Ï†ÑÏûêÏ±Ö, ÌïµÏã¨ ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏßÄÏπ®ÏúºÎ°ú ÏãúÏûëÌïòÏÑ∏Ïöî

posts.content:
AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞, Ïù¥Ï†úÎäî Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÏ≤òÎüº! Îã®ÏàúÌûà "ÏÜåÏÑ§ Ïç®Ï§ò"Î•º ÎÑòÏñ¥, Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÏ†ÅÏù∏ ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏Î°ú ÏôÑÏÑ±ÎèÑ ÎÜíÏùÄ Í∏ÄÏùÑ AIÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥Î≥¥ÏÑ∏Ïöî. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏúºÎ°ú Ï†ÑÏûêÏ±Ö Ï∂úÍ∞ÑÍπåÏßÄ Í∞ÄÎä•Ìï©ÎãàÎã§!

 

 Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ïù¥Î≤à ÏòÅÏÉÅÏóêÏÑú AIÎ•º ÌôúÏö©Ìïú Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞ÏôÄ ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏÉùÏÑ±Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú Í∞ïÏùòÎ•º ÏãúÏûëÌï¥Î≥¥Î†§Í≥† Ìï¥Ïöî. ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà ÎßêÌï¥ÏÑú, Ïù¥ Í∞ïÏùòÎ•º Îã§ Îì§ÏúºÏãúÎ©¥ Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÏùÄ Îã®ÏàúÌûà AIÏóêÍ≤å "ÏÜåÏÑ§ Ïç®Ï§ò"ÎùºÍ≥† ÌïòÎäî ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùÑ Ìõ®Ïî¨ Îõ∞Ïñ¥ÎÑòÏñ¥ÏÑú, ÎßàÏπò Ï†ÑÎ¨∏ ÏûëÍ∞ÄÏ≤òÎüº Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÏ†ÅÏù¥Í≥† ÏôÑÏÑ±ÎèÑ ÎÜíÏùÄ Í∏ÄÏùÑ AIÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ÎÇº Ïàò ÏûàÍ≤å Îê† Í±∞ÏòàÏöî.

Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎÜÄÎûçÍ≤åÎèÑ, Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎßåÎì† Í∏ÄÎ°ú Ïã§Ï†ú Ï†ÑÏûêÏ±ÖÏùÑ Ï∂úÍ∞ÑÌï¥ÏÑú ÏàòÏùµÍπåÏßÄ ÎÇº Ïàò ÏûàÎã§Îäî ÏÇ¨Ïã§, ÏïåÍ≥† Í≥ÑÏÖ®ÎÇòÏöî? Ï†ïÎßê ÎåÄÎã®ÌïòÏ£†? Ïò§Îäò Í∞ïÏùò Î™©Ï∞®Î•º Í∞ÑÎã®Ìûà ÏÜåÍ∞úÌï¥ÎìúÎ¶¨Î©¥, Î®ºÏ†Ä AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞Ïùò ÌòÑÏ£ºÏÜåÏôÄ Í∑∏ Ïû•Îã®Ï†êÏùÑ ÍººÍººÌûà ÏÇ¥Ìé¥Î≥º Í±∞Í≥†Ïöî, Í∑∏Îã§Ïùå ÏöîÏ¶ò Îú®Îäî Ï†ÑÏûêÏ±Ö Ï∂úÌåê ÏãúÏû•Ïùò ÌòÑÏã§Í≥º Î¨¥ÌïúÌïú Í∞ÄÎä•ÏÑ±ÎèÑ Ìï®Íªò ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.

Î¨¥ÏóáÎ≥¥Îã§ Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë Í∞úÎ∞úÌïú 'ÎßûÏ∂§Ìòï Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞ ÌîÑÎ°¨ÌîÑÌä∏ ÏÉùÏÑ± ÏßÄÏπ®'Ïùò ÌäπÏßïÍ≥º ÌôúÏö©Î≤ïÏùÑ Ï†ïÎßê ÏÉÅÏÑ∏ÌïòÍ≤å ÏÑ§Î™ÖÌï¥ ÎìúÎ¶¥ Í±∞ÏòàÏöî. Í∑∏ÎãàÍπåÏöî, Íµ¨ÎèÖ, Ï¢ãÏïÑÏöî Íæπ ÎàåÎü¨Ï£ºÏãúÍ≥† Í∞ïÏùò ÎÅùÍπåÏßÄ Îî∞ÎùºÏôÄÏÑú Ïó¨Îü¨Î∂ÑÎßåÏùò Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞ ÏãúÏä§ÌÖúÏùÑ Ï†úÎåÄÎ°ú Íµ¨Ï∂ïÌï¥Î≥¥ÏãúÍ∏∞ Î∞îÎûçÎãàÎã§!

 

AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞Ïùò ÌòÑÏ£ºÏÜåÏôÄ ÎÜÄÎùºÏö¥ Îä•Î†•

Î®ºÏ†Ä AI Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞Í∞Ä ÎèÑÎåÄÏ≤¥ Ïñ¥ÎîîÍπåÏßÄ ÏôîÎäîÏßÄ ÌïúÎ≤à ÏÇ¥Ìé¥Î≥ºÍπåÏöî? Î∂àÍ≥º 2~3ÎÖÑ Ï†ÑÎßå Ìï¥ÎèÑ AIÍ∞Ä Ïì¥ Í∏ÄÏùÄ Ï†ïÎßê Ìã∞Í∞Ä ÎßéÏù¥ ÎÇ¨ÏóàÏñ¥Ïöî. posts.content:
ChatGPT, ÎãπÏã†Ïùò ÎòëÎòëÌïú ÎπÑÏÑúÏùºÍπå, ÏïÑÎãàÎ©¥ Ï∞©Í∞ÅÏùò ÏãúÏûëÏùºÍπå? ÏùºÏÉÅÏóêÏÑú ChatGPTÎ•º ÌòÑÎ™ÖÌïòÍ≤å ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎäî ÎπÑÎ≤ïÍ≥º Ï£ºÏùòÌï† Ï†êÏùÑ ÌòÑÏßÅ Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÍ∞Ä ÏÜîÏßÅÌïòÍ≤å ÌååÌó§Ï≥ê Î¥ÖÎãàÎã§.

 

 ÏöîÏ¶ò Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑ÏùÑ Î≥¥Î©¥ Ïò®ÌÜµ ChatGPT Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÎøêÏù¥ÏóêÏöî. “ChatGPTÍ∞Ä Î™á ÎÖÑÍ∞Ñ Ìï¥Í≤∞ Î™ªÌïú Î¨∏Ï†úÎ•º Îã®Î≤àÏóê ÌíÄÏñ¥Ï§¨Îã§”Îäî Îë•, “ÎàÑÍ∞Ä ÏßàÎ¨∏ÌñàÎäîÎç∞, ÏßÑÏßú Í∏∞Í∞Ä ÎßâÌûå Ìï¥ÎãµÏùÑ Ï§¨Îã§”Îäî Îë•, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ “Í≥µÎ∂Ä, Í∏ÄÏì∞Í∏∞, ÏÉÅÎã¥, Ïó¨Ìñâ Í≥ÑÌöçÍπåÏßÄ Îã§ ÎêòÎçîÎùº!”Îäî Í≥ºÏû•Îêú(?) Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÍπåÏßÄ Ïã¨Ïã¨Ïπò ÏïäÍ≤å Îì§Î†§Ïò§Ï£†. ÏÜîÏßÅÌûà Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏñòÍ∏∞Îì§, Í≥ºÏû•Îêú Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÎèÑ ÏûàÏßÄÎßå ÏÇ¨Ïã§Ïù¥Í∏∞ÎèÑ Ìï¥Ïöî. Ï†ÄÎèÑ ÏùòÎ£å ÌòÑÏû•ÏóêÏÑú ÏùºÌïòÎäî Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Í∞ÄÎ°úÏÑú, ÏùòÌïô Î∂ÑÏïºÎäî Î¨ºÎ°†Ïù¥Í≥† ÏùºÏÉÅÏÉùÌôúÏùò Îã§ÏñëÌïú Î¨∏Ï†ú Ìï¥Í≤∞Ïóê ChatGPTÎ•º ÏßÅÏ†ë ÌôúÏö©Ìï¥Î≥¥Î©¥ÏÑú Í∑∏ Ïû†Ïû¨Î†•ÏùÑ Ï∂©Î∂ÑÌûà ÎäêÍºàÍ±∞Îì†Ïöî. 

Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Î¨∏Ï†úÎäî… ÎÑàÎ¨¥ ÎßéÏùÄ ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Ïù¥ ÎèÑÍµ¨Ïùò ÌïúÍ≥Ñ ÏóÜÏù¥ ÎßπÏã†ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Îäî Í≤ÅÎãàÎã§. Ï†úÍ∞Ä Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ Ïì∞Îäî Ïù¥Ïú†ÎèÑ Ïó¨Í∏∞Ïóê ÏûàÏñ¥Ïöî. ÏùºÎ∞òÏù∏Îì§Ïù¥ ChatGPTÎ•º Ïûò ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú ÌòÑÏã§Ï†ÅÏù∏ Í∏∞Ï§ÄÏÑ†ÏùÑ Í≥µÏú†ÌïòÍ≥†, ÏßÑÏßú Ïä§ÎßàÌä∏Ìïú ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÍ∞Ä Îê† Ïàò ÏûàÎèÑÎ°ù ÎèïÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏóàÍ±∞Îì†Ïöî.

 

‚úÖ ChatGPTÍ∞Ä ÎπõÏùÑ Î∞úÌïòÎäî ÏÉÅÌô©Îì§

Ï†ú Í≤ΩÌóòÏÉÅ, ChatGPTÍ∞Ä ÏßÑÏßú Ïú†Ïö©ÌïòÍ≤å ÎäêÍª¥ÏßÄÎäî ÏàúÍ∞ÑÎì§Ïù¥ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÌäπÌûà ÏïÑÎûòÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ ÏÉÅÌô©ÏóêÏÑúÎäî ‘Ïù¥Í±∞ ÏßÑÏßú Î¨ºÍ±¥Ïù¥Îã§!’ Ïã∂ÏùÑ ÎïåÍ∞Ä ÎßéÏïÑÏöî.

1. Ïù¥ÎØ∏ ÏïÑÎäî ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ Ï†ïÎ¶¨ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò ÌôïÏû•ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÑ Îïå 

“ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏïÑÎäî Ïù¥ Í∞úÎÖê, ÌòπÏãú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎÜìÏπú Î∂ÄÎ∂ÑÏùÄ ÏóÜÏùÑÍπå?”, “Ïù¥ ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥, Îã§Î•∏ Î∂ÑÏïºÏóêÏÑ† Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ï†ëÍ∑ºÌï†Íπå?”, “Í∏∞Ï°¥ Ï†ïÎ≥¥Î•º ÏâΩÍ≤å ÏöîÏïΩÌï¥Ï§Ñ Ïàò ÏûàÏùÑÍπå?” Ïù¥Îü∞ ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïñ¥Îäê Ï†ïÎèÑ ÏßÄÏãùÏùÑ Í∞ÄÏßÄÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÏÉÅÌÉúÏóêÏÑú ChatGPTÎ•º ÌôúÏö©ÌïòÎ©¥ Ï†ïÎßê Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Î≥¥Ï°∞ ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä Îê©ÎãàÎã§.

ÏòàÎ•º Îì§Ïñ¥, ÏöîÎ¶¨ Ïû¨Î£åÏùò ÎåÄÏ≤¥Ïû¨Î•º Ï∞æÍ±∞ÎÇò, ÏòÅÏñ¥ Î¨∏Ïû•ÏùÑ Îçî ÏûêÏó∞Ïä§ÎüΩÍ≤å Í≥†ÏπòÍ±∞ÎÇò, ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïì¥ ÏûêÍ∏∞ÏÜåÍ∞úÏÑúÎ•º Îçî ÍπîÎÅîÌïòÍ≤å Îã§Îì¨ÏùÑ Îïå ÎßêÏù¥Ï£†. Ïù¥ÎØ∏ ÏïåÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò Î≥¥ÏôÑÌï† Îïê ChatGPTÍ∞Ä ÏµúÍ≥† ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùò Ï°∞Î†•ÏûêÎùºÍ≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï©ÎãàÎã§.

2. Ï†ïÎ≥¥ÎüâÏù¥ ÎßéÍ≥† Ï†ïÌòïÌôîÎêú Î∂ÑÏïºÏóêÏÑ† Îçî Ïú†Ïö©Ìï¥Ïöî 

ChatGPTÎäî Î∞©ÎåÄÌïú Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º Í∏∞Î∞òÏúºÎ°ú ÌïôÏäµÎêòÏóàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê, Î¨∏ÌóåÏù¥ Ïûò Ï†ïÎ¶¨Îêú Î∂ÑÏïºÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÌäπÌûà Ï†ïÌôïÎèÑÍ∞Ä Îß§Ïö∞ ÎÜíÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ï†úÍ∞Ä ÏßÅÏ†ë Ïç®Î≥¥Îãà ÏßÑÏßú Ìé∏ÌïòÎçîÎùºÍ≥†Ïöî.

  • “ÌååÎ¶¨ÏóêÏÑú 3ÏùºÍ∞Ñ Ïó¨Ìñâ ÏùºÏ†ï Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å ÏßúÏïº Ìï†Íπå?”
  • “ÏóëÏÖÄÏóêÏÑú ÌäπÏ†ï ÏÖÄÏóê Îî∞Îùº ÏÉâÍπî Î∞îÍæ∏Îäî Ï°∞Í±¥Î∂Ä ÏÑúÏãùÏùÄ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Ìï¥?”
  • “ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÎßåÎì† ÎπÑÏ¶àÎãàÏä§ ÏïÑÏù¥ÎîîÏñ¥, Í∞ÑÎã®Ìïú SWOT Î∂ÑÏÑù Ìï¥Ï§ò.”

Ïù¥Î†áÍ≤å ÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÏùÑ Îïå ÎÑ§Ïä§ÌåÖÏù¥ ÎßàÏπò ÏïÑÎûòÏôÄ Í∞ôÏù¥ ÎÇòÎà†Ï†∏ÏÑú Ï†ÅÏö©ÎêúÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§.

posts.title: Ï†ëÍ∑ºÏÑ±ÏùÑ ÏßÄÏõêÌïúÎã§Îäî Ï∞©Í∞Å
Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï± ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî(Mobile App Obfuscation)ÎûÄ?
posts.content:
[![NHN Cloud_meetup banner_Obfuscation_202507-01.png](https://image.toast.com/aaaadh/real/2025/techblog/NHN%20Cloudmeetup%20bannerObfuscation20250701.png)](https://www.nhncloud.com/kr) ## Îì§Ïñ¥Í∞ÄÎ©∞: Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï± ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎûÄ? Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï†ÌîåÎ¶¨ÏºÄÏù¥ÏÖò(Ïù¥Ìïò ‚ÄòÏï±‚Äô)ÏùÄ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞ÏôÄ Í∏∞ÏóÖ ÏßÄÏãù Ïû¨ÏÇ∞Í∂åÏùÑ Î≥¥Ìò∏ÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Î≥¥Ïïà Ï°∞ÏπòÍ∞Ä Î∞òÎìúÏãú ÌïÑÏöîÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÌäπÌûà, Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÎÑ∑ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Ïï±Ïù¥ Ï†Ñ ÏÑ∏Í≥ÑÎ°ú Î∞∞Ìè¨ÎêòÎ©¥ÏÑú Ìï¥Ïª§Îì§Ïùò Í≥µÍ≤© ÎåÄÏÉÅÏù¥ ÎêòÍ∏∞ Ïâ¨ÏõåÏ°åÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÏÉÅÌô©ÏóêÏÑú **ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî(Obfuscation)**Îäî ÏÜåÏä§ ÏΩîÎìúÎÇò Î∞îÏù¥ÎÑàÎ¶¨ ÌååÏùºÏùÑ Î≥µÏû°ÌïòÍ≤å Î≥ÄÌôòÌïòÏó¨ Ïó≠Í≥µÌïô(ÈÄÜÂ∑•Â≠∏, Reverse Engineering) Î∞è Ìï¥ÌÇπ ÏãúÎèÑÎ°úÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ïï±ÏùÑ Î≥¥Ìò∏ÌïòÎäî ÌïµÏã¨ Í∏∞Ïà†Î°ú ÏûêÎ¶¨ Ïû°ÏïòÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑúÎäî Î™®Î∞îÏùº ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏóêÏÑú ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÏùò Ï§ëÏöîÏÑ±Í≥º Îã§ÏñëÌïú ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÎì§Ïù¥ Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎäî Í∏∞Îä•Îì§ÏùÑ ÏÇ¥Ìé¥Î≥¥Í≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.
## Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï± ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÏùò ÌïÑÏöîÏÑ± **Ïó≠Í≥µÌïô**, Ï¶â **Î¶¨Î≤ÑÏä§ ÏóîÏßÄÎãàÏñ¥ÎßÅ**ÏùÄ Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï± Î≥¥ÏïàÏóê ÌÅ∞ ÏúÑÌòëÏù¥ Îê©ÎãàÎã§. Ìï¥Ïª§Îì§ÏùÄ Ïï± ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º Î∂ÑÏÑùÌï¥ ÏûëÎèô ÏõêÎ¶¨Î•º ÌååÏïÖÌïòÍ≥†, Ïù¥Î•º ÌÜµÌï¥ Ï∑®ÏïΩÏ†êÏùÑ Ï∞æÏïÑÎÇ¥Í±∞ÎÇò ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º Î¨¥Îã®ÏúºÎ°ú Î≥ÄÍ≤ΩÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏïÖÏùòÏ†ÅÏù∏ Í≥µÍ≤©ÏûêÎì§ÏùÄ Î¶¨Î≤ÑÏä§ ÏóîÏßÄÎãàÏñ¥ÎßÅÏùÑ Ïù¥Ïö©ÌïòÏó¨ Ïï±Ïùò ÌïµÏã¨ Î°úÏßÅÏùÑ ÌÉàÏ∑®ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò, Ïú†Î£å Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Î¨¥Î£åÎ°ú ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÌïòÎèÑÎ°ù Ï°∞ÏûëÌïòÎ©∞, Ïã¨ÏßÄÏñ¥ ÏïÖÏÑ±ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º ÏÇΩÏûÖÌï¥ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏóêÍ≤å ÌîºÌï¥Î•º Ï§Ñ ÏàòÎèÑ ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÏúÑÌòëÏóê ÎåÄÏùëÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌïú Î∞©Î≤ï Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä Î∞îÎ°ú **ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî**ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎäî Ïï±Ïùò ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º ÏùΩÍ∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†µÍ≤å ÎßåÎì§Ïñ¥ Î¶¨Î≤ÑÏä§ ÏóîÏßÄÎãàÏñ¥ÎßÅÏùÑ Î∞©Ìï¥ÌïòÎäî Í∏∞Ïà†Î°ú, ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º ÎßàÏπò ÏïîÌò∏Ï≤òÎüº Î≥µÏû°ÌïòÍ≤å Î≥ÄÌôòÌïòÏó¨ Ìï¥Ïª§Í∞Ä Î∂ÑÏÑùÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†µÍ≤å ÎßåÎì≠ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Î°ú Ïù∏Ìï¥ Í≥µÍ≤©ÏûêÎäî ÏãúÍ∞ÑÍ≥º ÎÖ∏Î†•ÏùÑ Í≥ºÎèÑÌïòÍ≤å ÏÜåÎ™®ÌïòÍ≤å ÎêòÏñ¥, Í≥µÍ≤© ÏãúÎèÑÎ•º ÌÅ¨Í≤å Ï†ÄÏßÄÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎäî ÏïàÌã∞ ÎîîÎ≤ÑÍπÖ, ÏïàÌã∞ ÌÖúÌçºÎßÅ, Î¨¥Í≤∞ÏÑ± Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÍ≥º Í∞ôÏùÄ Îã§Î•∏ Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Ïà†Í≥º Î≥ëÌñâ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Îê† Îïå Í∑∏ Ìö®Í≥ºÍ∞Ä ÎçîÏö± Í∑πÎåÄÌôîÎê©ÎãàÎã§.
## ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Í∏∞Ïà†Ïùò Ï¢ÖÎ•ò „ÄåParvez Faruki Ïô∏, (2026). Android Code Protection via Obfuscation Techniques: Past, Present and Future Directions„ÄçÏóê Îî∞Î•¥Î©¥ ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Í∏∞Ïà†ÏùÄ Ï¥ù ÎÑ§ Í∞ÄÏßÄ Ïπ¥ÌÖåÍ≥†Î¶¨Î°ú Î∂ÑÎ•òÎê©ÎãàÎã§. > 1. Layout Obfuscation > 2. Control Obfuscation > 3. Preventive Obfuscation > 4. Data Obfuscation Ïó¨Í∏∞ÏÑúÎäî ÎààÏúºÎ°ú ÏâΩÍ≤å ÌôïÏù∏Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎäî **Layout Obfuscation**Í≥º **Control Obfuscation**Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ ÏûêÏÑ∏Ìûà ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í≤†ÏäµÎãàÎã§.
### **Layout Obfuscation** Layout ObfuscationÏùò ÎåÄÌëúÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î∞©ÏãùÏùÄ **ÏãùÎ≥ÑÏûê ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî**ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îäî ÏÜåÏä§ ÏΩîÎìú ÎÇ¥ Î≥ÄÏàò, Ìï®Ïàò, ÌÅ¥ÎûòÏä§ Îì±Ïùò Ïù¥Î¶ÑÏùÑ ÏùòÎØ∏ ÏóÜÎäî Î¨∏ÏûêÎÇò Ïà´ÏûêÎ°ú Î≥ÄÍ≤ΩÌïòÎäî Î∞©ÏãùÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Android Ïï±ÏóêÏÑúÎäî Ï£ºÎ°ú JavaÎÇò Kotlin ÏΩîÎìúÍ∞Ä, iOS Ïï±ÏóêÏÑúÎäî Objective-C ÎÇò Swift ÏΩîÎìúÍ∞Ä ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÎåÄÏÉÅÏù¥ Îê©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ Í∏∞Ïà†ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Ìï¥Ïª§Í∞Ä ÏΩîÎìúÏóêÏÑú ÏùòÎØ∏ ÏûàÎäî Îã®Ïñ¥Î•º Ï∞æÍ±∞ÎÇò Ïï±Ïùò Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ ÌååÏïÖÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†µÍ≤å ÎßåÎì≠ÎãàÎã§. #### **Ïû•Ï†ê** * ÏΩîÎìú Í∞ÄÎèÖÏÑ±Ïù¥ ÌÅ¨Í≤å ÎÇÆÏïÑÏ†∏ Ïó≠Í≥µÌïô ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä ÏΩîÎìúÏùò Íµ¨Ï°∞ÎÇò Ïó≠Ìï†ÏùÑ ÌååÏïÖÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†µÏäµÎãàÎã§. * Îã®ÏàúÌïú Î≥ÄÌôòÎßåÏúºÎ°úÎèÑ ÏÉÅÎãπÌïú Î≥¥Ïïà Ìö®Í≥ºÎ•º ÏñªÏùÑ Ïàò ÏûàÏñ¥ Ï¥àÍ∏∞ Î≥¥Ïïà Í∞ïÌôî ÏàòÎã®ÏúºÎ°ú Ìö®Í≥ºÏ†ÅÏûÖÎãàÎã§. #### **Îã®Ï†ê** * ÏßÄÎÇòÏπòÍ≤å ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎêú ÏΩîÎìúÎäî ÎîîÎ≤ÑÍπÖÏù¥ÎÇò Ïú†ÏßÄÎ≥¥ÏàòÍ∞Ä Ïñ¥Î†§ÏõåÏßà Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. * ÏΩîÎìú ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôîÏôÄ Ï∂©ÎèåÌï† Í∞ÄÎä•ÏÑ±Ïù¥ ÏûàÏñ¥ ÏÑ±Îä•Ïóê ÎØ∏ÏπòÎäî ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Í≥†Î†§Ìï¥Ïïº Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. **ÏõêÎ≥∏ ÏΩîÎìú** ```java public class UserData { private String userName; private String userPassword; public String getUserName() { return userName; } public void setUserPassword(String password) { this.userPassword = password; } } ``` **ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎêú ÏΩîÎìú** ```java public class a { private String b; private String c; public String a() { return b; } public void b(String d) { this.c = d; } } ```
### **Control Obfuscation** Control ObfuscationÏùÄ ÏΩîÎìúÏùò Ïã§Ìñâ Í≤ΩÎ°úÏôÄ Ï†úÏñ¥ ÌùêÎ¶ÑÏùÑ Î≥µÏû°ÌïòÍ≤å Î≥ÄÍ≤ΩÌïòÎäî Í∏∞Ïà†ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Ï°∞Í±¥Î¨∏, Î∞òÎ≥µÎ¨∏, Î∂ÑÍ∏∞Î¨∏Ïùò ÏàúÏÑúÎ•º Ïû¨Íµ¨ÏÑ±ÌïòÍ±∞ÎÇò Î∂àÌïÑÏöîÌïú ÏΩîÎìú Ï°∞Í∞ÅÏùÑ ÏÇΩÏûÖÌïòÏó¨ Ïã§Ï†ú Î°úÏßÅÍ≥º ÌòºÎèôÏùÑ Ïú†Î∞úÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Î≥ÄÌôòÏùÄ Ïó≠Í≥µÌïô ÎèÑÍµ¨Í∞Ä Ïã§Ï†ú Ïã§Ìñâ Í≤ΩÎ°úÎ•º ÌååÏïÖÌïòÎäî Îç∞ ÎßéÏùÄ ÏãúÍ∞ÑÍ≥º ÎÖ∏Î†•ÏùÑ ÌïÑÏöîÎ°ú ÌïòÍ≤å ÎßåÎì≠ÎãàÎã§. #### **ÏòàÏãú** * Ïã§Ï†ú Î°úÏßÅÍ≥º Î¨¥Í¥ÄÌïú Ï°∞Í±¥Î¨∏Í≥º Î∞òÎ≥µÎ¨∏ÏùÑ Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÌï¥ Ï†úÏñ¥ ÌùêÎ¶ÑÏùÑ Î≥µÏû°ÌïòÍ≤å ÎßåÎì≠ÎãàÎã§. * Ìï®Ïàò Ìò∏Ï∂ú ÏàúÏÑúÎ•º ÏûÑÏùòÎ°ú Î≥ÄÍ≤ΩÌïòÏó¨ ÏΩîÎìú ÌùêÎ¶ÑÏùÑ Ï∂îÏ†ÅÌïòÍ∏∞ Ïñ¥Î†µÍ≤å Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. #### **Ìö®Í≥º** * Í≥µÍ≤©ÏûêÍ∞Ä Ïï± ÎÇ¥Î∂ÄÏùò Ïã§Ï†ú ÎèôÏûëÏùÑ Î∂ÑÏÑùÌïòÎäî Îç∞ ÏÜåÏöîÎêòÎäî ÏãúÍ∞ÑÏù¥ ÌÅ¨Í≤å Ï¶ùÍ∞ÄÌï©ÎãàÎã§. * Ïó≠Í≥µÌïô ÎèÑÍµ¨Î•º Ïù¥Ïö©Ìïú ÏûêÎèô Î∂ÑÏÑùÏùò Ï†ïÌôïÎèÑÎ•º ÎÇÆÏ∂∞ Î≥¥ÏïàÏÑ±ÏùÑ Í∑πÎåÄÌôîÌï©ÎãàÎã§. ÎåÄÌëúÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Flattening Í∏∞Î≤ïÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Ïù¥Î•º ÌôïÏù∏Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. **ÏõêÎ≥∏ ÏΩîÎìú** ```java public class Calculator { public int calculate(int a, int b) { int result = a + b; return result * 2; } } ``` **ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎêú ÏΩîÎìú** ```java public class Calculator { public int calculate(int a, int b) { int result = 0; int state = 0; int opaque = (a * b) % 2 + 1; // Ìï≠ÏÉÅ 1 ÎòêÎäî 2 while (opaque > 0) { switch (state) { case 0: result = a + b; state = opaque; // Ï°∞Í±¥Ïóê Îî∞Îùº 1 ÎòêÎäî 2Î°ú Ï†ÑÌôò break; case 1: result = result * 2; // Í≥±ÏÖà ÏàòÌñâ state = 3; // Ï¢ÖÎ£åÎ•º ÏúÑÌï¥ 3 Î∂ÄÏó¨ break; case 2: // ÏùòÎØ∏ ÏóÜÎäî Ïó∞ÏÇ∞(dead code) result = b - a; state = 1; break; case 3: // Ï¢ÖÎ£å opaque = -1; // Î£®ÌîÑ Ï¢ÖÎ£å(Ïã§Ï†úÎ°ú Î∂àÌïÑÏöî) break; } if (opaque < 0) break; // ÎçîÎØ∏ ÏΩîÎìú Î∞è ÌÉàÏ∂ú Ï°∞Í±¥ } return result; } } ```
## ÏãúÏû•Ïóê Ï°¥Ïû¨ÌïòÎäî Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï± ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò Î™®Î∞îÏùº ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏùÄ Î¨¥Î£åÏôÄ ÏÉÅÏö© Ï†úÌíàÏúºÎ°ú Íµ¨Î∂ÑÎê©ÎãàÎã§. Í∞Å ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏùÄ Í∏∞Îä•, ÏÇ¨Ïö© Ìé∏ÏùòÏÑ±, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÏóÖÎç∞Ïù¥Ìä∏ ÏßÄÏõê Ï∏°Î©¥ÏóêÏÑú Ï∞®Ïù¥Í∞Ä ÏûàÏúºÎ©∞, Í∞úÎ∞úÏûêÏùò ÌïÑÏöîÏóê Îî∞Îùº ÏÑ†ÌÉùÌï† Ïàò ÏûàÏäµÎãàÎã§. ### **Î¨¥Î£å ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò** #### **Proguard** ProguardÎäî Android Í∞úÎ∞ú ÌôòÍ≤ΩÏóêÏÑú Í∞ÄÏû• ÎÑêÎ¶¨ ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÎêòÎäî Ïò§Ìîà ÏÜåÏä§ ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÎèÑÍµ¨ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. Java Í∏∞Î∞òÏùò ÏΩîÎìúÎ•º ÎåÄÏÉÅÏúºÎ°ú ÏãùÎ≥ÑÏûê ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÏôÄ ÏΩîÎìú ÏµúÏ†ÅÌôî, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† Î∂àÌïÑÏöîÌïú ÏΩîÎìú Ï†úÍ±∞ Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌï©ÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥ ÎèÑÍµ¨Îäî Android StudioÏôÄ ÌÜµÌï©ÎêòÏñ¥ ÏûàÏñ¥ ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïù¥ Îß§Ïö∞ Í∞ÑÌé∏Ìïú Ï†êÏù¥ ÌÅ∞ Ïû•Ï†êÏûÖÎãàÎã§. * Ï£ºÏöî Í∏∞Îä• * ÏãùÎ≥ÑÏûê ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Î∞è ÏΩîÎìú ÏïïÏ∂ï * Î∂àÌïÑÏöîÌïú ÏΩîÎìú Ï†úÍ±∞Î•º ÌÜµÌïú Ïï± ÌÅ¨Í∏∞ Í∞êÏÜå * ÏûêÎèôÌôîÎêú ÏÑ§Ï†ïÍ≥º ÎπåÎìú ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§ÏôÄÏùò ÏõêÌôúÌïú ÌÜµÌï© Control ObfuscationÏùò Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÄ Ï†úÍ≥µÎêòÏßÄ ÏïäÏäµÎãàÎã§. #### **Black Obfuscation** OpenSourceÎ°ú Ï†úÍ≥µÎêòÍ≥† ÏûàÎäî ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÏûÖÎãàÎã§. * Ï£ºÏöî Í∏∞Îä• * Control flow flattening * If Î∂ÑÍ∏∞Î¨∏ ÌùêÎ¶Ñ Î≥ÄÍ≤Ω * Î≥µÏû°Ìïú Î™ÖÎ†πÏñ¥Î°ú ÏπòÌôò ÏãùÎ≥ÑÏûê ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÏôÄ Í∞ôÏùÄ Layout ObfuscationÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÏäµÎãàÎã§. #### **Í∑∏ Î∞ñÏùò OpenSource** * ObfusApk * [https://github.com/ClaudiuGeorgiu/Obfuscapk](https://github.com/ClaudiuGeorgiu/Obfuscapk) * dprotect * [https://obfuscator.re/dprotect/](https://obfuscator.re/dprotect/)
### **ÏÉÅÏö© ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò** #### **DÏÇ¨ ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò** ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Í∏∞Îä•Ïóê ÎçîÌï¥, Î¨∏ÏûêÏó¥ ÏïîÌò∏Ìôî, ÏΩîÎìú ÏÇΩÏûÖ, ÎîîÎ≤ÑÍπÖ Î∞©ÏßÄ Îì± Îã§ÏñëÌïú Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌï©ÎãàÎã§. #### **QÏÇ¨ ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò** ÏΩîÎìú ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî, Î≥ÄÏ°∞ Î∞©ÏßÄ, Îü∞ÌÉÄÏûÑ Î≥¥Ìò∏ Îì± Îã§ÏñëÌïú Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎäî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏûÖÎãàÎã§. #### **NHN AppGuard ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî** NHN CloudÏùò NHN AppGuardÎäî ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî(Layout Î∞è Control Obfuscation)ÎøêÎßå ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, Î≥ÄÏ°∞ Î∞©ÏßÄ, Îü∞ÌÉÄÏûÑ Î≥¥Ìò∏, ÏïàÌã∞ ÎîîÎ≤ÑÍπÖ, ÏïàÌã∞ ÌÖúÌçºÎßÅ Îì± Îã§Ï∏µÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎäî ÌÜµÌï© Î™®Î∞îÏùº Î≥¥Ïïà ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏûÖÎãàÎã§. NHN AppGuardÏùò ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎäî Î≥¥Ïïà Î™®ÎìàÍ≥ºÏùò ÏÉÅÌò∏ÏûëÏö©ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï¥ Control FlowÎ•º Î≥ÄÎèôÏãúÏºú ÎçîÏö± Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ Ï†úÍ≥µÌï©ÎãàÎã§. > [NHN AppGuard Îçî ÏïåÏïÑÎ≥¥Í∏∞](https://www.nhncloud.com/kr/service/security/nhn-appguard)
## ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò ÏÑ†ÌÉù Í∏∞Ï§Ä * **ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Í∞ïÎèÑ**: ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏù¥ Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÎäî ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî Í∏∞Ïà†Ïùò Ï¢ÖÎ•òÏôÄ Í∞ïÎèÑÎ•º ÌôïÏù∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. * **ÏßÄÏõê Í∏∞Îä•**: ÎîîÎ≤ÑÍπÖ Î∞©ÏßÄ, Î≥ÄÏ°∞ Î∞©ÏßÄ, Îü∞ÌÉÄÏûÑ Î≥¥Ìò∏ Îì± Ï∂îÍ∞ÄÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ ÏßÄÏõêÌïòÎäîÏßÄ ÌôïÏù∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. * **ÏÑ±Îä• ÏòÅÌñ•**: ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎ°ú Ïù∏Ìï¥ Ïï± ÏÑ±Îä•Ïóê ÎØ∏ÏπòÎäî ÏòÅÌñ•ÏùÑ Í≥†Î†§Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. * **ÏÇ¨Ïö© Ìé∏ÏùòÏÑ±**: ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏùò ÏÇ¨Ïö© Î∞©Î≤ïÏù¥ ÏñºÎßàÎÇò ÏâΩÍ≥† Ìé∏Î¶¨ÌïúÏßÄ ÌôïÏù∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. * **Í∏∞Ïà† ÏßÄÏõê**: ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò Ï†úÍ≥µ ÏóÖÏ≤¥Ïùò Í∏∞Ïà† ÏßÄÏõê ÏàòÏ§ÄÏùÑ ÌôïÏù∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. * **Í∞ÄÍ≤©**: ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖòÏùò Í∞ÄÍ≤©Í≥º ÎùºÏù¥ÏÑ†Ïä§ Ï†ïÏ±ÖÏùÑ ÌôïÏù∏Ìï©ÎãàÎã§.
## ÎÇòÍ∞ÄÎ©∞ Ïò§ÎäòÎÇ† Í∞ïÎ†•Ìïú Î™®Î∞îÏùº Ïï± Î≥¥ÏïàÏùÄ ÏÑ†ÌÉù ÏÇ¨Ìï≠Ïù¥ ÏïÑÎãå ÌïÑÏàò ÏöîÍ±¥ÏûÖÎãàÎã§. ÌäπÌûà Î¶¨Î≤ÑÏä§ ÏóîÏßÄÎãàÏñ¥ÎßÅÏùÄ Ïï±Ïùò ÏßÄÏãù Ïû¨ÏÇ∞Í∂åÏùÑ Ïπ®Ìï¥ÌïòÍ≥† ÏÇ¨Ïö©Ïûê Îç∞Ïù¥ÌÑ∞Î•º ÏúÑÌòëÌïòÎäî Ïã¨Í∞ÅÌïú Í≥µÍ≤© Î∞©ÏãùÏúºÎ°ú Î∂ÄÏÉÅÌñàÏäµÎãàÎã§. Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú ÏúÑÌòëÏóê Ìö®Í≥ºÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú ÎåÄÏùëÌïòÍ∏∞ ÏúÑÌï¥ÏÑúÎäî Ï†ÑÎ¨∏Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÎÇúÎèÖÌôî ÏÜîÎ£®ÏÖò ÎèÑÏûÖÏù¥ Ï§ëÏöîÌïòÏßÄÎßå, ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎßåÏúºÎ°úÎäî ÏôÑÎ≤ΩÌïú Î≥¥ÏïàÏùÑ Î≥¥Ïû•Ìï† Ïàò ÏóÜÏäµÎãàÎã§. ÏßÑÏ†ïÌïú Ïï± Î≥¥ÏïàÏùÄ ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÎøêÎßå ÏïÑÎãàÎùº Îã§ÏñëÌïú Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Ïà†Îì§Ïù¥ Ïú†Í∏∞Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Í≤∞Ìï©Îê† Îïå Ïã§ÌòÑÎê©ÎãàÎã§. NHN AppGuardÎäî Ïù¥Îü¨Ìïú Îã§Ï∏µÏ†ÅÏù∏ Î≥¥Ïïà Í∏∞Îä•ÏùÑ ÌÜµÌï©Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ï†úÍ≥µÌïòÏó¨ ÎÇúÎèÖÌôîÏùò ÌïúÍ≥ÑÎ•º Í∑πÎ≥µÌïòÍ≥†, ÎçîÏö± Í∞ïÎ†•ÌïòÍ≥† Í≤¨Í≥†Ìïú Ïï± Î≥¥Ìò∏ Ï≤¥Í≥ÑÎ•º Íµ¨Ï∂ïÌï©ÎãàÎã§. NHN AppGuardÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò Í∑ÄÏÇ¨Ïùò ÏÜåÏ§ëÌïú Ïï±ÏùÑ ÏïàÏ†ÑÌïòÍ≤å Î≥¥Ìò∏ÌïòÍ≥†, ÎπÑÏ¶àÎãàÏä§ ÏÑ±Í≥µÏùÑ ÏúÑÌïú Îì†Îì†Ìïú ÌÜ†ÎåÄÎ•º ÎßàÎ†®ÌïòÏãúÍ∏∞ Î∞îÎûçÎãàÎã§. Í∏¥ Í∏ÄÏùÑ ÏùΩÏñ¥ Ï£ºÏÖîÏÑú Í∞êÏÇ¨Ìï©ÎãàÎã§. posts.content:
üìå Í∞úÏöî

ÏòàÏ†ÑÏùò ÎÇòÏóêÍ≤å ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏ÎûÄ Îã®ÏßÄ ‚ÄòÍµ¨ÌòÑÏù¥ ÎÅùÎÇú ÌõÑ, Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏù¥ ÏóÜÎäîÏßÄ ÌôïÏù∏ÌïòÎäî ÎßàÏßÄÎßâ Ï†àÏ∞®‚ÄôÏòÄÎã§.
ÌïòÏßÄÎßå ÏßÄÍ∏àÏùÄ Îã§Î•¥Îã§. ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏Îäî Ïù¥Ï†ú ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Íµ¨ÌòÑÌï¥Ïïº Ìï†ÏßÄÎ•º ÏïåÎ†§Ï£ºÎäî ÏÑ§Í≥Ñ ÏßÄÏπ®ÏÑúÎã§.

Ïù¥ Í∏ÄÏóêÏÑúÎäî ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏Í∞Ä ÎÇ¥ Í∞úÎ∞ú Î∞©ÏãùÍ≥º ÏÇ¨Í≥†Î•º Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å Î∞îÍøîÎÜìÏïòÎäîÏßÄ, Í∑∏Î¶¨Í≥† ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÎäî Ï¢ãÏùÄ ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏ÎûÄ Î¨¥ÏóáÏù∏ÏßÄÎ•º Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥Î≥¥Î†§ ÌïúÎã§

üìå E2E ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏

E2E(End-to-End) ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏Îäî ÏÇ¨Ïö©ÏûêÏùò ÏöîÏ≤≠Ïù¥ ÌîÑÎ°†Ìä∏ÏóîÎìúÎ•º Í±∞Ï≥ê Î∞±ÏóîÎìúÏôÄ DBÍπåÏßÄ Ïó∞Í≤∞ÎêòÎäî Ï†ÑÏ≤¥ ÌùêÎ¶ÑÏùÑ Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌïòÎäî ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏Îã§.

Ïù¥ Îã®Í≥ÑÏóêÏÑúÏùò ÌÖåÏä§Ìä∏Îäî Ïã§Ï†ú DBÎÇò Íµ¨ÌòÑ Î°úÏßÅ ÏóÜÏù¥ÎèÑ APIÏùò Ïù∏ÌÑ∞ÌéòÏù¥Ïä§ÏôÄ ÌùêÎ¶ÑÏùÑ Í≤ÄÏ¶ùÌïòÎäî Îç∞ Î™©Ï†ÅÏù¥ ÏûàÎã§.

ÌéÄÎìúÎ†àÏù¥ÏßïÌïòÎäî Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ Í∞ÄÏû• Ïã†Í≤Ω Ïç®Ïïº ÌïòÎäî Í±¥ Î∞îÎ°ú ÌòÑÏã§Í≥º Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùÑ Ï≤†Ï†ÄÌûà Íµ¨Î∂ÑÌïòÎäî Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä ÌïòÎäî Ïùº Ï§ë Í∞ÄÏû• ÌÅ∞ ÎπÑÏ§ëÏùÑ Ï∞®ÏßÄÌïòÎäî Í±¥ ÎãπÏó∞Ìûà Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§ÏùÑ ÎßåÎÇòÎäî Í±¥Îç∞, Ïù¥ Ï§ë ÎãπÏû• Ìà¨ÏûêÏú†ÏπòÎ•º ÌïòÏßÄ ÏïäÎäî Î∂ÑÎì§ÎèÑ ÏûàÏßÄÎßå, ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ ÌòÑÏû¨ ÌéÄÎìúÎ†àÏù¥Ïßï Ï§ëÏù¥Í≥†, Ïä§Ìä∏Î°±ÏóêÍ≤å Ìà¨ÏûêÎ∞õÍ∏∞Î•º Ìù¨ÎßùÌïòÎäî Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥Îã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨ÎèÑ ÏõåÎÇô ÎßéÏùÄ ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïòÍ≥† Ìà¨Ïûê Ïú†ÏπòÍ∞Ä Í∏âÌïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§Ïóê Í≤ÄÌÜ†Ïùò Ïö∞ÏÑ†ÏàúÏúÑÎ•º Ìï†ÎãπÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú ÏùºÏùÑ Ï≥êÎÇ¥Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê Ìï≠ÏÉÅ ÌïòÎäî ÏßàÎ¨∏ Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÍ∞Ä ÌéÄÎìúÎ†àÏù¥Ïßï ÌÉÄÏûÑÎùºÏù∏Ïù¥Îã§. Ï¶â, Ïù¥Î≤à Ìà¨ÏûêÏú†ÏπòÍ∞Ä ÏñºÎßàÎÇò Í∏âÌïúÍ∞ÄÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏßàÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Í∞Ä Í∏çÏ†ïÏ†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïòÎäî ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïù∏Îç∞, ÌòÑÍ∏àÏù¥ ÏïÑÏä¨ÏïÑÏä¨Ìï¥ÏÑú Í∏àÎ∞© Îü∞Ïõ®Ïù¥Í∞Ä ÎÅùÎÇòÎäî ÏÉÅÌô©Ïù¥Î©¥ Ïö∞ÏÑ†ÏàúÏúÑÎ•º ÎÜíÍ≤å ÌïòÍ≥† Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïúÎã§. ÎòêÌïú, Îã§Î•∏ VCÏôÄÎèÑ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞ÌïòÍ≥† ÏûàÍ≥†, Î™áÎ™á Ìà¨ÏûêÏûêÎì§Í≥ºÏùò ÎåÄÌôîÍ∞Ä ÍπäÍ≤å ÏßÑÌñâÎêòÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§Î©¥, Ïù¥Îü∞ ÌöåÏÇ¨Îì§ÎèÑ Ïö∞Î¶∞ Ïö∞ÏÑ†ÏàúÏúÑÎ•º ÎÜíÍ≤å ÌïòÍ≥† Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌïúÎã§. ÎäêÎÇåÏù¥ Ï¢ãÏùÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏù∏Îç∞, Ïö∞Î¶¨Ïùò Î∞îÏÅú ÏÉÅÌô© ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïóê ÎäêÎ¶¨Í≤å Í≤ÄÌÜ†ÌñàÎã§Í∞Ä Îã§Î•∏ VCÏóêÍ≤å Ìà¨ÏûêÎ•º Î∞õÍ≥† ÎùºÏö¥ÎìúÍ∞Ä ÎßàÎ¨¥Î¶¨ÎêòÎäî Í≤ΩÏö∞ÎèÑ Ï¢ÖÏ¢Ö ÏûàÍ∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.
Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä ÏöîÏÉà ÏïÑÏ£º ÏûêÏ£º ÎäêÎÅºÎäî Í±¥, ÏÉÅÎãπÌûà ÎßéÏùÄ Ï∞ΩÏóÖÍ∞ÄÎì§Ïù¥ VCÎì§Ïùò ÏùòÌñ•Ïóê ÎåÄÌï¥ÏÑú Ï∞©Í∞ÅÌïòÍ≥†, ÌòÑÏã§ÏùÑ ÎòëÎ∞îÎ°ú Î™ª Î≥¥Í≥† Î≥∏Ïù∏Îì§Ïù¥ Î∞îÎùºÎäî Ïù¥ÏÉÅÎåÄÎ°ú ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌïòÍ≥† ÎØøÎäîÎã§Îäî Ï†êÏù¥Îã§.
Ï°∞Í∏à Îçî Íµ¨Ï≤¥Ï†ÅÏúºÎ°ú Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìï¥ Î≥¥Î©¥, Î™á Îã¨ Ï†ÑÏóê Ìïú ÌöåÏÇ¨Î•º ÎßåÎÇ¨ÎäîÎç∞ ÍΩ§ Í¥úÏ∞ÆÎã§Í≥† ÏÉùÍ∞ÅÌñàÎã§. Í∑∏Îü∞Îç∞ Ïñ¥ÎñªÍ≤å 3Ï£º ÏïàÏóê ÎßàÎ¨¥Î¶¨ÌïúÎã§Îäî Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Í∞Ä ÎÇòÏôîÎäîÏßÄ Î¨ºÏñ¥Î≥¥Îãà, ÏÉÅÎãπÌûà Ìô©ÎãπÌï¥ÌïòÎ©¥ÏÑú, Í∑∏Í±¥ Í∑∏ VCÏùò ÏùºÎ∞òÏ†ÅÏù∏ Ìà¨Ïûê ÌîÑÎ°úÏÑ∏Ïä§Ïóê Í¥ÄÌï¥ Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Ìïú Í±¥Îç∞, ÎåÄÌëúÏù¥ÏÇ¨Í∞Ä Ï≤†Ï†ÄÌïòÍ≤å Î≥∏Ïù∏Ïù¥ Ïù¥Ìï¥ÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂ÏùÄ Îç∞Î°ú Î∞õÏïÑÎì§Ïù∏ Í≤É Í∞ôÎã§Í≥† ÌñàÎã§.

Îß§Ï∂ú 1,000Ïñµ ÏõêÏùÑ ÌïòÎ©¥ ÎåÄÎ∂ÄÎ∂Ñ 5,000Ïñµ Ïõê Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùò Í∏∞ÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏπòÏóê Ìà¨ÏûêÎ•º Î∞õÍ±∞ÎÇò, 1Ï°∞ Ïõê Ïù¥ÏÉÅÏùò Í∏∞ÏóÖÍ∞ÄÏπòÏóê Îçî ÌÅ∞ ÌöåÏÇ¨Ïóê Ïù∏ÏàòÎêòÎäî ÏÇ¨Î°ÄÎ•º ÏµúÍ∑º Î™á ÎÖÑ ÎèôÏïà Ïó¨Îü¨ Î≤à Î¥§Í∏∞ ÎïåÎ¨∏Ïù¥Îã§.

ÏùºÎ∞ò ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Î®πÍ≥† ÎßàÏãúÍ≥† Î∞îÎ•¥Í≥† ÏûÖÎäî Ï†úÌíàÏùò Îã®Í∞ÄÍ∞Ä Í∑∏Î†áÍ≤å ÎπÑÏã∏ÏßÄ ÏïäÎã§Îäî Í±∏ Í∞êÏïàÌïòÎ©¥, ÏóÑÏ≤≠ÎÇòÍ≤å ÎßéÏù¥ ÌåîÏïÑÏïºÏßÄ Îß§Ï∂ú 1,000Ïñµ ÏõêÏùÑ Îã¨ÏÑ±Ìï† Ïàò ÏûàÎã§. ÎÇ¥Í∞Ä Ïù¥ Î∏îÎ°úÍ∑∏ÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ Î™á Î≤à Ïñ∏Í∏âÌñàÎäîÎç∞, ÎßàÌïòÌä∏Í∞Ä Í∞ÑÎîîÏùò Î™ÖÏñ∏ Ï§ë ÌïòÎÇòÏù∏, ‚ÄúÏ≤òÏùåÏóî ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ ÎãπÏã†ÏùÑ Î¨¥ÏãúÌï† Í≤ÉÏù¥Í≥†, Í∑∏Îã§ÏùåÏóî ÎãπÏã†ÏùÑ ÎπÑÏõÉÏùÑ Í≤ÉÏù¥Í≥†, Îã§ÏùåÏóî ÎãπÏã†Í≥º Ïã∏Ïö∏ Í≤ÉÏù¥Í≥†, Í∑∏Îü¨Í≥† ÎÇòÏÑú ÎãπÏã†ÏùÄ Ïù¥Í∏∏ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§‚ÄùÏóêÏÑú ÎåÄÍ∏∞ÏóÖÎì§Ïù¥ 1,000Ïñµ Îß§Ï∂ú ÌïòÎäî Ïä§ÌÉÄÌä∏ÏóÖÏùÑ ÎåÄÌïòÎäî ÏûêÏÑ∏Îäî ‚ÄúÎã§ÏùåÏóî ÎãπÏã†Í≥º Ïã∏Ïö∏ Í≤ÉÏù¥Îã§‚Äù Î∞îÎ°ú Í∑∏ ÏßÅÏ†ÑÏùò ÏÉÅÌÉúÍ∞Ä ÏïÑÎãêÍπå Ïã∂Îã§.
